awd_titl_txt: ICE-T: RC: Performance Evaluation of Advanced Wireless Network Edge Infrastructure - Network Simulation & Test Beds
awd_abstract_narration:
The open source network simulation (ns-3) tool is used widely by researchers to evaluate the performance of computer networks. Over the past decade, user demand for new ns-3 capabilities has centered on simulating rapidly emerging wireless networking technologies including Wireless Fidelity (WiFi) and Long Term Evolution (LTE) cellular systems. New capabilities are essential for exploration of emerging 5th Generation (5G) cellular network technologies.

This project seeks to 1) extend the core wireless capabilities of ns-3, positioning the simulator as the research tool of choice for 5G wireless network simulations; 2) improve usability and create new educational/training materials; and 3) better align ns-3 with experiments on wireless network test-beds. The latter project goal is expected to contribute to recently announced National Science Foundation-funded Platforms for Advanced Wireless Research (PAWR) city-scale advanced wireless infrastructure testbeds. New wireless technology coexistence scenarios for heterogeneous networks as well as the ongoing challenge of scaling due to network densification are main research thrusts for this effort.  In addition, a key project goal is improving usability and development of new ns-3 educational material to ease adoption of these new modules (and ns-3 broadly) by the next generation of users. The project extends an existing collaboration between investigators at the University of Washington and the Centre Technologic Telecomunicacions Catalunya (CTTC Barcelona).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This effort was oriented towards performance evaluation of features in nextG (early 5th Gen) wireless networks, with two concrete objectives:

 1. Improve ns-3 models for nextG wireless, while leveraging/amplifying existing relations with EU partners, notably CTTC Barcelona who contributed the 4G LTE-LENA ns-3 stack, 

2. Improve usability of ns-3 by the community by seeking better alignment of ns-3 in emulation mode with experimentation using wireless network test-beds such as NSF PAWR (in US) and similar EU testbeds

Re 1: This effort provided the foundation for new PHY abstraction models for complex link simulations such as MIMO-OFDM. Principles for fast simulations were established that led to significant improvements in ns-3 runtime and resulting code contributed to ns-3 development branch repositories (Gitlab). The fast methods developed for MIMO channel generation and computation of effective SNR  are being adopted by groups building on our work for more advanced simulation scenarios, attesting to its broad appeal and utility.  Further information is available @ 

https://depts.washington.edu/funlab/projects/improvements-to-ns-3-simulator/ns-3-scaling-for-next-g-wireless-networks/ 

Re 2: Results from ns-3 alignment with NSF POWDER testbed was reported in Annual 2021 ns-3 workshop tutotial, see ``Using ns-3 with POWDER Wireless TestBed" 

https://www.nsnam.org/research/wns3/wns3-2021/tutorials and also archived on Vimeo https://vimeo.com/567675867. 

Similarly, CTTC contributed 2022 tutorial on ``NR, NR-U and NR-V2X ns-3 Models", see  https://www.nsnam.org/research/wns3/wns3-2022/tutorials/

CTTC's release of Rel-15 compatible 5G-NR ns-3 RAN suite in 2019 provided further timely impetus. 

Finally, the award was also instrumental in expanding US-EU collaboration: 2 visiting research scholars from IMDEA Networks (Madrid, Spain) and U. Padova respectively, were hosted at the PI's laboratory with partial support. 


Last Modified: 02/12/2023
Modified by: Sumit Roy
